issue.title: Improved pattern matching in DataCollectionAnnotationReader
issue.body:
Second attempt at #214.

It's now backwards compatible with the generic notation without `TKey`.

comment.body: @rubenvanassche would you be able to include this one in a new release?
If you can use fake models for the central connection you'll only need one database which, among other things, allows you to do parallel testing.

pull_request.title: [4.x] Refactor cached tenant resolvers
pull_request.body:
Still draft, but I was working on some refactoring that makes it easier to swap implementations in user land. Next to that, using the service container and less `static` properties allows us to work towards supporting Octane.

This PR tries to refactor the CachedTenantResolvers with a decorator pattern. The three implementations of TenantResolver no longer know about caching at all. Instead, in the service provider we create the TenantResolvers.

Also added a TenantRepository interface which makes testing the tenant resolvers in isolation a bit easier.

Let me know what you think, I'm happy to do some refactoring work!

To do:
- [ ] Make invalidating cache work again.
- [ ] Find a solution for `DomainTenantResolver::$currentDomain`, should not be static.
- [ ] Cleanup TenantResolver creation in service provider.

repo.name: tenancy
repo.description: Automatic multi-tenancy for Laravel. No code changes needed.

pull_request.body:
Still draft, but I was working on some refactoring that makes it easier to swap implementations in user land. Next to that, using the service container and less `static` properties allows us to work towards supporting Octane.

This PR tries to refactor the CachedTenantResolvers with a decorator pattern. The three implementations of TenantResolver no longer know about caching at all. Instead, in the service provider we create the TenantResolvers.

Also added a TenantRepository interface which makes testing the tenant resolvers in isolation a bit easier.

Let me know what you think, I'm happy to do some refactoring work!

issue.title: [4.x] Refactor cached tenant resolvers
issue.body:
Still draft, but I was working on some refactoring that makes it easier to swap implementations in user land. Next to that, using the service container and less `static` properties allows us to work towards supporting Octane.

This PR tries to refactor the CachedTenantResolvers with a decorator pattern. The three implementations of TenantResolver no longer know about caching at all. Instead, in the service provider we create the TenantResolvers.

Also added a TenantRepository interface which makes testing the tenant resolvers in isolation a bit easier.

Let me know what you think, I'm happy to do some refactoring work!

To do:
- [ ] Make invalidating cache work again.
- [ ] Find a solution for `DomainTenantResolver::$currentDomain`, should not be static.
- [ ] Cleanup TenantResolver creation in service provider.

comment.body: @stancl I understand that the package is very intertwined with how Laravel works but there is an argument to be made for the repositories, not per se for unit tests but to test one part of the application on it's own. In most applications the majority of the code you write will be related to a tenant but to test that code you'll need two databases: the central one and the tenant one. Having a repository for the "central" models allow you to swap them out for fake ones so you'll only need the tenant database and not the central one. This will also unlock the usage of parallel testing which is otherwise not possible since it will assume one database per test.

Having a tenant (and domain) repository is very useful for testing. Because it allows you to test on one connection (`tenant`) because you can swap out the repository for the models in the central one for a fake implementation.

issue.title: Conditional return types for collections
issue.body:
Resolves #158 

This adds conditional return types for collections so that `phpstan` knows which collection type is being returned (`DataCollection`, `PaginatedDataCollection`, `CursorPaginatedDataCollection`)

There is [an issue](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan/issues/7740) and that is that it doesn't seem to properly work with interfaces, so (for now) it checks for the `CursorPaginator` and `Paginator` classes rather than interfaces.
Once that bug has been fixed we can update the conditional return type to check for the contracts, but it still might be worth getting this in before that.

comment.body: @rubenvanassche it's not required for the functionality. It's kind of like a test file for types that gets checked by phpstan to ensure that it works and keeps working in the future. It's similar to how Laravel does this: https://github.com/laravel/framework/tree/9.x/types

issue.body:
Resolves #158 

This adds conditional return types for collections so that `phpstan` knows which collection type is being returned (`DataCollection`, `PaginatedDataCollection`, `CursorPaginatedDataCollection`)
